cohort.bio: The ability to identify a problem, evaluate solutions, and implement a plan are qualities which have been essential to my responsibilities in every job role I have held.  I am always seeking constant education in and out of the workplace to better myself so that I may be of greater value today than I was yesterday.  The driving force for pursuing software development is a direct action guided by my enjoyment and aptitude in problem solving and continuous growth.  Throughout my studies and application of React.js and C#/.NET I have grown fond of the entire development process and the capacity to forge with a new medium.

cohort.reelThemIn: No matter how many mistakes you make or how slow you progress, you are still way ahead of everyone who isn’t trying. - Tony Robbins
cohort.bio: Working as a quality technician for the past several years within the automotive industry has allowed me to wear many hats, from shipping to destructive weld testing to auditing. Throughout, I have been looking for that job that I liked, that I wanted to get out of bed for, a job that both presented a challenge and allowed me to be creative. Learning to code with the other developers at Nashville Software School has been one of the more challenging and rewarding experiences of my life and I look forward to continuing this journey beyond the classroom.

cohort.reelThemIn: If you aren't in over your head, how do you know how tall you are? - T.S. Eliot
cohort.bio: I am a family man who loves the outdoors, traveling and adventures. Born and raised in Michigan, I moved to Tennessee in 2010 and fell in love with this part of the country. In my previous professional life,I was a cartographer and spatial data purveyor doing all kinds of neat stuff. Software development is my passion and the renewed focus in my life.

cohort.reelThemIn: It always seems impossible until it's done. - Nelson Mandela
cohort.bio: My interest in computers and technology piqued from an early age, when I began teaching myself HTML & CSS at the age of 13. At the time, I had no idea that my love of tinkering could become a career that would feed my incurable curiosity. I originally heard about Nashville Software School from a colleague while working at Apple and decided to apply to the Apprenticeship program, not even imagining I would be accepted. Looking back, I can see how it has changed my life in ways that I had never anticipated. I am thrilled to continue my journey as a developer and to continually grow and improve.

cohort.reelThemIn: Words empty as the wind are best left unsaid. - Homer
cohort.bio: I've enjoyed tinkering with computer hardware since I was young, so when a friend suggested software development with Ruby, it seemed like a perfect fit. It is so rewarding to conceive an idea in my mind and turn it into an actual functioning product. After working on software development in my own free time, I came to NSS to receive formal training in a field that recently became a hobby to me. Upon my graduation, I would like to use my skills to create user-friendly systems that connects various groups of people and fosters global community.

cohort.reelThemIn: Never underestimate the power of dreams and the influence of the human spirit. We are all the same in this notion. The potential for greatness lives within each of us. - Wilma Rudolph
cohort.bio: I have been interested in technology for as long as I can remember. I corrupted countless family computers. The first time I held a smartphone I felt as if I had the entire world in my hands. My interest has only grown as I’ve gotten older. I graduated from Lipscomb University with a degree in Business Administration. I have been lucky enough to obtain a unique perspective in Nashville’s healthcare industry. I spent fours years at a diagnostic start-up and then another three at a large health system. At each stop I heavily relied on technology to improve processes but I wanted to take it a step further. I wanted to create in the technology space. Enter Nashville Software School. The past year has been so challenging yet extremely rewarding. The front-end and back-end were equally unique and interesting. I’m excited put to use some of the technologies learned over the program. I have a tremendous amount of respect for my fellow classmates. They are awesome people and talented developers. Hire them.

cohort.reelThemIn: Dude, you can't stay here if you're gonna stank it up with your bad vibes, man! - Jake the Dog
cohort.bio: I have always enjoyed doing work that at the end of the day you can see the fruits of your labor and that is the main thing i enjoy about software development. I have always been around the software development field. Both my parents as well as my brother have worked in the filed their whole lives and are a major reason why I wanted to involved myself. I got to see first hand the process they went through while working and then the satisfaction they felt when a project was done. I couldnt help but want to be able to create amazing things like them and feel that same sense of accomplishment

cohort.reelThemIn: We have nothing, if not belief. - Reepicheep
cohort.bio: Drake Morrison is a Full Stack Software Developer who enjoys exploring the design of problem-solving strategies. Drake values simple, clear, and concise solutions to problems while working in a collaborative team environment. He loves to discover new ideas connected to the process of designing and crafting software. Away from computers he is fond of long hikes in the mountains, and practicing Martial Arts. A bookworm who takes pleasure in running games of Dungeons & Dragons for his friends, Drake is always trying out new mechanics to create an awesome experience for his players. Drake is a person who is deeply interested in “why?” Finding answers to those questions is a lifelong adventure and something that enhances both his professional and personal pursuits while bringing value to those around him.

cohort.reelThemIn: If you never try, you'll never know what you are capable of. - John Barrow
cohort.bio: I have worked in many different roles and industries prior to becoming a software engineer: Supply Chain, Inventory Management, Accountant, DBA, Application Support, and SQL Developer. While I have enjoyed all of these, there has been one element missing, which is freedom. Over the years, I have been challenged with not being able to improve work efficiency due to the fact that many applications in the market are not fully compatible or suitable with what I was trying to accomplish. I began to ask myself, “Why rely on others to create what I need? Why can’t I create the tools I need to help myself and others?” With my programming skills, I can successfully carry out my ideas with the freedom I have been seeking.

cohort.reelThemIn: A project a day keeps imposter syndrome away. - Lenora Porter
cohort.bio: For as long as I can remember, I’ve been very curious about how things come to be. I’m always interested in the smallest details. That same curiosity is how I found my way into the world of web development. After finding my MySpace page and remembering how fun coding the themes were, I thought I would give coding a serious chance! I began my journey by teaching myself, but realized that I could get much more out of the experience in a classroom setting. After a little research, I found my way to Nashville Software School. Nashville Software School has taught me how to think like a developer and how to write clean, readable code. It has also taught me to believe in myself in this field. I once had a horrible case of imposter syndrome, but thanks to the awesome community this school provides, I’ve been able to apply myself and build some pretty awesome projects! I am so excited to continue my journey as a web developer and can’t wait to teach other little girls that they too can code pretty awesome projects!

cohort.reelThemIn: A funny thing happens when we start keeping promises to ourselves. We become unstoppable. - Ken Fite
cohort.bio: I've always been a tinkerer, from the Christmas morning where I taught myself to hook up the Nintendo because I didn't want to wait on my parents, to building out my own silly adventure games using batch files in DOS, to building the computers themselves, and now to building the software that runs on them. I love being able to take control and make the things happen that I want to see, and I live for the "eureka!" moments, the sense of pride and accomplishment when your creation takes shape and comes to life. I took a big risk and moved here to Nashville four years ago to get my foot in the door of the IT world and finance my continuing education. Now, thanks to Nashville Software School and a renewed sense of exhilaration, I'm ready to start my journey as a professional software developer.

cohort.reelThemIn: I intend to live forever, so far so good. - Steven Wright
cohort.bio: At the time, it seemed like bad luck to be graduating from college with a music business degree in 2007 while the music industry was toppling and a economic recession was looming. However, this has lead to a fun and interesting journey which ultimately brought me to Nashville Software School. As my guaranteed job in the music industry was rescinded due to layoffs, I found myself searching for work in other fields. From graduation until 2012 I worked as a farmer, drummer, cook, barista, and eventually as an Assistant Plant Manager making wood flooring. In 2013 I obtained an MBA and was promoted to Plant Manager, until I made my move back to Nashville in 2015 to be with my young family. During this time, I had the privilege of staying home with my children while working part time. This afforded me the opportunity to do some soul searching in regards to finding a meaningful and fulfilling career. I had always been interested in learning about new technologies and had found myself studying software development through sites like code academy and team treehouse. I had some close friends who worked in development that persuaded me to look into Nashville Software School. NSS has turned out to be one of the best decisions I have ever made. I have found a great amount of satisfaction from learning to code in such a fast paced environment. Continuous learning is a huge intrinsic motivator for me, and am incredibly excited about continuing my career path as developer.

cohort.reelThemIn: Your life is made of two dates and a dash. Make the most of the dash. - Linda Ellis
cohort.bio: With a background in media production, I was able to work with developers on new websites. I found this to be very intriguing. I slowly started to learn Web and Software development on my own. Years later I enrolled in Nashville Software School to become a full-stack developer. The best part about development is it's constantly changing.

cohort.reelThemIn: Keep on Keepin' on - Joe Deertay
cohort.bio: I am a type of person the enjoys the outdoors and good ole fashion hard work. The feeling of a successful attempt at a task is what drives me to push forward. In my studies of software development, I find that the hard work that is put into coding anything is extremely satisfying and that is my 'why' for becoming Software Developer.

cohort.reelThemIn: When you have exhausted all possibilities, remember this - you haven't. - Thomas Edison
cohort.bio: As a child, I tested cookie recipes in my Easy-Bake Oven, conducted science experiments with household items and built toy robots. I wanted to understand how ideas became final products. For the last 6 years, I’ve specialized in digital advertising operations/marketing/site management and along the way, something sparked a realization that I was missing an integral piece to my career path puzzle. I was led to study web development at Nashville Software School after uncovering digital ad fraud in a previous position where the malicious events were executed by code. I felt a responsibility to prevent such events from occurring to my employers in the future and it ignited a new hunger in me to explore programming. Now, I’m excited to take all of the skill sets I’ve gained from previous positions/school and utilize them to my fullest potential as I grow my career in technology.

cohort.reelThemIn: Education is the great engine of personal development. - Nelson Mandela
cohort.bio: My desire to cultivate my problem-solving skill and creativity led me to Nashville Software School. Although the road was a bit bumpy once I started this journey, with a lot of prayer, perseverance and hard work I have made it to the finish line of this programme and have entered a world of continuous learning. Outside of NSS I am a mother of two, who enjoys looking at the smile on my kids face when I act silly with them. I also enjoy attending events or reading books about personal development/self awareness.

cohort.reelThemIn: The world is but a canvas for our imagination. - Henry David Thoreau
cohort.bio: As a maker at heart, I am most happy when I am creating things. You can usually find me woodworking, crafting, or hiking in the backcountry. Software development was a natural fit for a creative outlet, and provides a constant challenge. Studying art and graphic design, I was always exposed to web development and it slowly peaked my interest. After trying to teach myself how to program, I realized development was the perfect career path for me and decided to take the deep dive. I owe everything I know to the awesome people at Nashville Software School, you guys are awesome!

cohort.reelThemIn: Whether you think you can, or you think you can't--you're right. - Henry Ford
cohort.bio: I received a Bachelor of Business Administration, with a concentration in Music Business, from Belmont University in 2006. For the past 10+ years, I've worked in the book industry and held positions in marketing, advertising, sales, and operations. In each role, I've sought out ways to streamline processes and find more efficient ways to complete my work. In 2016, I began experimenting with developing an application to automate an onboarding process I created for work and quickly became engrossed with all the ways technology can solve problems and create value for people. I began reading everything I could find related to technology, listening to podcasts, and watching videos on sites like Lynda.com and Team Treehouse. By 2017 I was hooked and had applied to the Nashville Software School to formalize my training as a software developer. I enjoy building applications that connect people with one another in a meaningful way, add efficiencies to existing processes, and/or improve the life of the user.

cohort.reelThemIn: You miss 100% of the shots you don't take. -Wayne Gretzky. - Michael Scott
cohort.bio: I have always been fascinated by modern technology and its implementation in real world problem solving. I truly enjoy immersing myself in learning new technologies and being in environments that nurture the cultivation of knowledge. Through my experience, I have been interested in both back-end and front-end development, though I feel great satisfaction watching immediate changes occur in React. I am eager to further discover the utilizations of new and different technologies and data structures.
